Headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Doubles Down On US Chipmaking, Plans $165 Billion Investment
Story:
Taiwan Semiconductor Doubles Down On US Chipmaking, Plans $165 Billion InvestmentTaiwan Semiconductor plans to invest $100 billion in U.S. for advanced semiconductor manufacturing, creating thousands of jobs and supporting AI development.

On Tuesday, contract chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (NYSE:TSM) announced plans to invest an additional $100 billion in advanced semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S.

Building on the company's ongoing $65 billion investment in its advanced semiconductor manufacturing operations in Phoenix, Arizona, Taiwan Semiconductor's total investment in the U.S. will likely reach $165 billion. The expansion includes plans for three new fabrication plants, two advanced packaging facilities, and a significant R&D team center.

Also Read: Intel Gains Traction With 18A Process As Nvidia, Broadcom Consider Manufacturing Contracts

The contract chipmaker expects to create hundreds of billions of dollars in semiconductor value for AI and other cutting-edge applications. The expanded investment will likely support 40,000 construction jobs over the next four years and create tens of thousands of high-paying, high-tech jobs in advanced chip manufacturing and R&D.

It will likely drive over $200 billion of indirect economic output in Arizona and across the U.S. in the next decade, the company said.

Taiwan Semiconductor's Arizona fab currently employs more than 3,000 people on 1,100 acres of land in Arizona. The site has been in volume production since late 2024.

U.S. President Donald Trump has been a critic of Taiwan since his presidential campaign days for accusing them of allegedly stealing American semiconductor business. He promised action against the country and threatened retaliatory tariffs because of Taiwan's large trade surplus with the U.S.

IDC expects the Taiwanese contract chipmaker to command a 67% share of the global foundry market in 2025, up 300 bps year over year.

Separate reports indicated the U.S. government canvassing Taiwan Semiconductor to help bail out Intel Corp (NASDAQ:INTC) out of its woes via strategic acquisition.

Meanwhile, Big Tech giants remain aggressively invested in their AI ambitions. Apple Inc (NASDAQ:AAPL), a key Taiwan Semiconductor client, committed over $500 billion to AI and advanced manufacturing.

Price Action: TSM stock traded higher by 1.48% to $175.53 premarket at the last check on Tuesday.

Also Read:

 * Amazon Web Services Bets Big On India with $8.2 Billion Cloud Investment

Headline: TSMC is dropping a $100 billion investment in the US
Story:
TSMC is dropping a $100 billion investment in the USMar 04, 2025

In its ongoing trade war with China, the US just scored a major win. President Donald Trump has announced that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) will make an investment of $100 billion in the US. Trump also called them the “most powerful company in the world.”

TSMC’s $100 billion investment in the US is just one of several investments the company has made over the years. TSMC has fabs located in its home turf of Taiwan. It also operates in China and Germany. In 2020, the company made its first expansion to the US, opening up shop in Arizona. The company had committed $65 billion to building three factories in Arizona. The latest $100 billion investment will go toward two additional chip manufacturing facilities located in Phoenix. This brings the total investment to $165 billion.

Expanding its US presence

The company’s investment follows that of its long-time partner and customer, Apple, which announced its own $500 billion investment in the US economy. According to Dr. C.C. Wei, TSMC Chairman and CEO, “Back in 2020, thanks to President Trump’s vision and support, we embarked on our journey of establishing advanced chip manufacturing in the United States. This vision is now a reality. AI is reshaping our daily lives and semiconductor technology is the foundation for new capabilities and applications. With the success of our first fab in Arizona, along with needed government support and strong customer partnerships, we intend to expand our U.S. semiconductor manufacturing investment by an additional $100 billion, bringing our total planned investment to $165 billion.”

TSMC’s ever-growing presence

TSMC is a major player in the semiconductor industry. In fact, it would be accurate to call the company the largest semiconductor company in the word. TSMC has many notable customers under its belt. This includes Apple. The Cupertino company heavily relies on TSMC’s advanced manufacturing capabilities to produce chipsets used in the iPhone, iPad, and Mac computers.

TSMC also supplies semiconductors to other major industry players. This includes NVIDIA, who is one of the largest producers of hardware used in AI development. They also supply chipsets to Qualcomm, whose Snapdragon components can be found in almost every Android device out there.

The company’s investment in the US will help grow its operations further, but it’s not hard to see that it is also a political move, one designed to stay in Trump’s good graces while he remains the President of the US.

The post TSMC is dropping a $100 billion investment in the US appeared first on Android Headlines.

Headline: Trump: China's invasion of Taiwan would be "catastrophic"
Story:
Trump: China's invasion of Taiwan would be "catastrophic"An invasion of Taiwan by China "would obviously be a catastrophic event," said Trump at a White House ceremony, announcing an investment in the United States by Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturing giant TSMC, worth 100 billion dollars (95 billion euros).

This investment "will at least give us a position where we will have, in this very, very important business, a very large share in the United States," said Trump.

Trump has successively avoided clarifying his position on US protection of Taiwan against an invasion by China, a scenario not ruled out by Beijing, which claims sovereignty over the island that has an autonomous, democratically elected government.

"I never comment on that (...) I don't comment on that because I don't want to put myself in that position," said the US President last week, when asked about his administration's position in the event of an invasion of Taiwan.

Washington's treatment of long-standing allies - threatening to seize the Danish territory of Greenland or make Canada the 51st province of the United States, for example - has unsettled other partners who depend on US support, such as Tawan.

Last week, Trump also reiterated that he has a "great relationship" with Chinese President Xi Jinping and said that Washington welcomes good relations with Beijing.

"I hear so many things about not wanting China in this country (...). That's not true. We want them to invest in the United States. That's good. There's a lot of money coming in and we're going to invest in China. We're going to do things with China. The relationship we're going to have with China is going to be very good," said the US President.

Although the US wants to have a good relationship with China, he said, "they're not going to be able to take advantage of us like they did with [former President Joe] Biden".

Trump's investment in TSMC today was negotiated by Biden and had already been announced by him.

Headline: TSMC To Invest $100 Billion To Expand Chip Manufacturing In US, Trump Announces
Story:
TSMC To Invest $100 Billion To Expand Chip Manufacturing In US, Trump AnnouncesThe move aligns with Trump's broader push to boost investments in American manufacturing. It will support the development of three new advanced chip plants, expanding beyond TSMC's existing facility and two ongoing projects in Arizona. The expansion is expected to generate tens of thousands of jobs. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, plans to invest $100 billion in the United States, in addition to the $65 billion it had previously announced, President Donald Trump announced Monday.

This move aligns with Trump's broader push to boost investments in American manufacturing. The investment will support the development of three new advanced chip plants, expanding beyond TSMC's existing facility and two ongoing projects in Arizona. The expansion is expected to generate tens of thousands of jobs, CNN [https://edition.cnn.com/2025/03/03/tech/tsmc-trump-meeting-chipmaking-investment/index.html] reported.

Trump Hails TSMC Investment As Key To U.S. Economic Security

Speaking alongside TSMC CEO C.C. Wei at the White House, President Trump hailed the investment as a critical step for enhancing U.S. economic security. TSMC is a key supplier of semiconductors to major tech companies such as Apple, Intel, and Nvidia.

"Semiconductors are the backbone of the 21st century economy. And really, without the semiconductors, there is no economy," the president said, according to AP News [https://apnews.com/article/trump-tsmc-chip-manufacturing-tariffs-42980704ffca62e823182422ee4b7b83] .

"Powering everything from AI to automobiles to advanced manufacturing, we must be able to build the chips and semiconductors that we need right here in American factories with Americans skill and American labor," Trump added.

"This is a tremendous move by the most powerful company in the world. It's a matter of economic security, it's also a matter of national security for us," Trump further said, adding that it will also help TSMC diversify away from its current chipmaking operations in Taiwan.

According to Trump, TSMC's investment — along with other similar initiatives — could help the United States capture 40% of the global chipmaking market.

"We're going to produce many chips to support AI progress and to support smartphones progress," Wei said. He also thanked TSMC customers such as Apple, Nvidia, AMD and Qualcomm.

Following the announcement, an Nvidia spokesperson said in a statement that TSMC's new fabs "will be the foundational pillar of a new technology supply chain centered in the United States," adding the company "will fully utilize TSMC's global manufacturing network to enhance our supply agility and resilience."

TSMC Investment, U.S. Chip Policy, And Trump's Tariff Strategy

According to CEO C.C. Wei, TSMC's $165 billion investment will create thousands of high-paying jobs. In 2022, former President Joe Biden signed the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act to boost U.S. chip manufacturing, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic.

The pandemic caused many overseas chip factories to close, leading to severe supply shortages. This disruption affected industries, halting car production and contributing to inflation. Trump criticized the CHIPS Act, advocating instead for high tariffs on imported chips to incentivize domestic production.

Job Cuts & Geopolitical Concerns Amid TSMC Investment

Also, on Monday, 40 employees from the U.S. Commerce Department who were involved in the CHIPS Act were fired as part of Trump's efforts to reduce the federal workforce, according to sources familiar with the decision.

When asked whether the new investment could help minimize the impact on the U.S. in the event that China isolates or seizes Taiwan, Trump said that it was impossible to "minimize" such a scenario, calling it "a catastrophic event."

Last week, Trump met Apple CEO Tim Cook at the White House. Following the meeting [https://www.ibtimes.com/apple-claims-software-switching-racist-trump-bug-3764909] , Apple announced a $500 billion investment in the U.S. over the next four years, including a new server factory in Texas.

Headline: Trump announces $100 billion investment in U.S. from TSMC, calls it 'most powerful company' in world
Story:
Trump announces $100 billion investment in U.S. from TSMC, calls it 'most powerful company' in worldTaiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is set to inject $100 billion into expanding its chip manufacturing operations in the United States, President Donald Trump announced Monday. The move significantly boosts TSMC's total U.S. investment to $165 billion and will fund the construction of five new fabrication facilities in Arizona.

Hailing the investment as a 'tremendous move by the most powerful company in the world,' Trump emphasized its role in advancing America's position as a global leader in artificial intelligence and semiconductor production. TSMC, a key supplier for Nvidia and Apple, plays a critical role in AI chip manufacturing.

The announcement aligns with the Trump administration's broader push to strengthen U.S. AI infrastructure and semiconductor independence. Last month, Trump unveiled a multibillion-dollar AI infrastructure project in collaboration with Oracle, OpenAI, and SoftBank. He has consistently advocated for reshoring semiconductor manufacturing, citing both economic and national security concerns.

Trump has previously accused Taiwan of undermining U.S. chip manufacturing and has promoted tariffs on semiconductor imports. However, TSMC has been expanding its U.S. footprint for years. The company initially committed $12 billion in 2020 for its first Arizona plant, later increasing its investment to $65 billion with a third factory. TSMC has also secured $6.6 billion in subsidies from the U.S. Commerce Department.

Wendell Huang, TSMC's Chief Financial Officer, expressed confidence that the new administration would continue to support the company's expansion efforts. A spokesperson for Nvidia affirmed that the company would leverage TSMC's global manufacturing network to enhance supply chain resilience.

This latest investment marks a major step in bolstering America's semiconductor industry, reinforcing its strategic importance in the AI revolution.

Headline: TSMC (TSM) Pre-Market Gains on $100 Billion U.S. Investment Plan
Story:
TSMC (TSM) Pre-Market Gains on $100 Billion U.S. Investment PlanMar 04, 2025

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM, Financial) experienced a 1.6% rise in pre-market trading, reaching $175.75. The increase follows TSMC's announcement of an additional $100 billion investment in its U.S. facilities. This decision aligns with efforts to boost domestic chip production and support manufacturing initiatives in the United States.

CEO C.C. Wei stated that the investment supplements a previously planned $65 billion allocation. Analyst Ming-Chi Kuo from Tianfeng International Securities regarded this strategic move as a win-win situation, positioning TSMC to maximize shareholder value. Kuo noted that while the investment amount appears substantial, lack of regulatory specifics allows TSMC flexibility to adapt to future conditions, likely safeguarding profitability.

Headline: Trump announces $100 billion investment by chipmaker TSMC
Story:
Trump announces $100 billion investment by chipmaker TSMCUS President Donald Trump announced on Monday an investment of 100 billion dollars from the world's largest manufacturer of advanced chips, Taiwan's TSMC, in line with the plan activated years ago by Washington to increase domestic semiconductor production.

The plan announced by Trump at the White House contemplates that the Taiwanese giant will invest that amount, which is in addition to another $65 billion it already committed to disburse last year, over the next few years in Phoenix (Arizona), where it already owns a plant that recently began operating and plans to open two additional ones in 2028 and 2030.

As explained by Trump and C.C. Wei, CEO of TSMC, the capital investment would go to these three factories and two others (including one for integrated circuit encapsulation), also located in the state of Arizona. With this capital investment, Trump said that between 20,000 and 25,000 new jobs would be created and that the US will be close to producing 40% of the world's advanced chips.

This expands TSMC's plan to disburse on U.S. soil, which had so far committed to the previous administration to invest some $65 billion in this country. Under President Joe Biden's administration the company was awarded a grant package valued at about $6.6 billion under the chip bill passed in 2022.

The supply of chips is considered a matter of national security in the US - as Trump recalled today - and this rule seeks to attract semiconductor production, especially of the most sophisticated integrated circuits, to the domestic arena in order to be less dependent on foreign supply chains.

It is estimated that TSMC, which still concentrates its production mainly in Taiwan, holds around 90% of the global market share of advanced integrated circuits, essential for US companies such as Nvidia or Apple and technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI) or the internet of things (IoT).

There is uncertainty as to whether the Trump administration, which at the time called the 2022 chip bill "very bad", will maintain that subsidy program.

For his part, U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick added even more doubt on the matter, noting Monday at the White House that TSMC has committed to this additional investment without the need for further subsidies and that it has done so in order to "be able to avoid paying tariffs."

Trump has floated the idea of eliminating the chip bill and imposing 25% tariffs on large semiconductor manufacturers as a pressure measure to locate higher production volumes on U.S. soil.
